column1: Whole Person Physiome Table for Urinary System

List physiological functions as a hierarchy, starting with the body system in Function/1 (this should be the same as the table name), a major life function in Function/2, and more specific functions in subsequent columns. Add more columns if needed. Place limited explanatory text if needed in Function/Notes. Each function should include a ID from Gene Ontology (GO) if possible or another standard ontology. The LABEL column is the label for that ID as it appears in that ontology.
column26: Provide a very brief description (a few words) of the specific processes that occur during the corresponding function (e.g., a chemical reaction, physical change, feedback loop, etc.).
column30: Indicate the time scale category for this process: milliseconds, seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, years.
column31: List anatomical structures involved in the physiological function as a hierarchy, starting with an organ in Structure/1, part of an organ in Structure/2, and smaller sub-parts in subsequent columns. Add more columns if needed. For the LABEL and ID columns, use UBERON if possible or FMA as an alternative ontology.
column55: OPTIONAL: Cell (with ID if possible) to specify certain tissues or cell types within the anatomical structure
column61: OPTIONAL FOR NOW. List clinical measures, such as laboratory tests, vital signs, or radiology studies, related to the physiological function. These columns are simple lists and are NOT hierarchical. Include an ID for the measurement, such as a LOINC code, if known. Add more columns if needed.
column73: OPTIONAL FOR NOW. List other interacting physiological functions. These columns are simple lists and NOT hierarchical. Add more columns if needed. For the LABEL and ID columns, use Gene Ontology (GO) if possible.
column85: DO NOT FILL THIS OUT YET. These columns will list body states or conditions that change the physiological process. (e.g., "fed", "fasted")
column87: DO NOT FILL THIS OUT YET. These columns will indicate the changes that occur during the corresponding body states. (e.g., "increase", "decrease")
column89: REQUIRED. Enter references in support of the information on this row. The ID column should include a standard identifier, such as a DOI or ISBN. The optional CHAPTER column should be used to list the relevant chapters in a book. The optional NOTES column can be used to clarify which part of the row the reference is for, such as a reference about the anatomical structures involved in the function rather than the interactions. Add more sets of reference columns if needed, making sure to include the ID column.

↓ Na levels in the tubular fluid will be monitored by the macula densa cells (MD) of the distal straight tubule (DST); ↓blood pressure will be monitored by baroreceptors and JG cells->RAAS->↑Na+ reabsorbtion
  ↑plasma osmolarity monitered by hypothalamic osmpreceptors,↓blood pressure monitored by baroreceptors ->neurons within the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei-> ↑ADH(neurohypophysis)->↑H2O reabsorption by collecting ducts

  ↓plasma osmolarity monitered by hypothalamic osmpreceptors,↑blood pressure monitored by baroreceptors ->neurons within the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei-> ↓ADH(neurohypophysis)->↓H2O reabsorption by collecting ducts
